messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of thedirector721
> Sent: Montag, 4. Februar 2008 22:34
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: How would you arrange tests with jUnit?
>
> >
> > The best thing with JUnit testing is to think in terms of
> behaviours.
> > What behaviour are you expecting from your system and write a test
> for
> > that. Do not let the fact that some behaviours span
> multiple objects
> > while others use only a single method cause you to lose
> sight of the
> > fact that testing is best done at the unit level and the most
> workable
> > unit is the unit of behaviour.
> >
>
> You make an excellent point, and something I didn't realize.
> I was thinking unit testing as 'test each method of my class'
> and make sure they work as expected. But really, I'm looking
> to test and see if my application functionality (behaviour)
> works. "Can I create a report"
> is what I'm really after...
>
> Thanks again.

I also make the experience to think in terms of behaviors of the
class under test and the methods. For myself I think thats the best
way to test the special class behavior as also method behavior in
one test class. But more over I use the following way...
If classes have similar behaviors, for example definied by
interfaces or abstract classes I group my tests into similar
classes, for example *ViewTest, *ServiceTest. That saves many
time of coding tests for similar classes with the same expected
behavior. The very nice side-effect: test methods stay in the
right test classes.

Imagine you have a complex service with dozens of methods and
each method is definied with up to 5 differently action paths.
So you may get up to 100 test methods in one class under test.
My own solutions is to devide it into some test classes for
example an AccountingService that provides serveral methodes
for accounting and some other central accounting information
to test:

BaseAccountOperationServiceTest
(tests the base account operations: add, sub, exceptions)
AdvancedAccountOperationServiceTest
(tests the advanced account operations: dispo, change)
TempAccountServiceTest
(tests the additonal behavior of temporary acccounts)
CustomerServiceAccountingServiceTest
(tests the behavior of the AccountingService in conjunction
of the customer service thats used by the AccountingService)

Back to your case I would write one test class CreateReportReportManagerTest
to test all behaviors of report creation. I assume that your
ReportManager has some other behaviors not only creation. So you write
ExportReportManagerTest, PrintReportManagerTest and some other ...ReportManagerTest
to separate the behavior a little bit. Maybe further development shows
you some general export or print behavior to test in separate
testcases.
